snippet.textDisplay: I went in with low expectations given the reviews.  We really enjoyed it! It was certainly better than the other two.  Yeah the script is weak, Finn and Poe are just weak characters.  Lando was great, 3PO was great and not overused, Kylo and Rey were decent.  If it had tighter focus from the beginning it would have been much better, but this was a good way to end this series of movies.  I do think Disney plus is the future of Star Wars, Mando is great and it allows for great storytelling.

snippet.textDisplay:
So basically, JJ Abrams set up all the pins for Rian Johnson to make something compelling to build upon when he made The Force Awakens.. and Rian Johnson decided to destroy it all to go his own way, forcing Abrams to have to waste half a movie trying to fix those problems so he could bring it to the conclusion he'd mapped out for them, but they didn't follow and then said there was no 'guide' to. Despite the fact Daisy Ridley saying that there was INDEED a path. Rian Johnson just didn't follow it.

Biggest thing I take from this is, JJ should have made all 3 films. Not only that, but Kathleen Kennedy should have had more respect for TFA to tell Rian Johnson to dial back all his changes, but be cause he was making the movie SHE wanted, she didn't.. and that's how this mess all started. The Last Jedi effectively is the puzzle piece that does not fit and throws off everything else.

JJ gave them on a silver platter the Golden Goose after all TFA did to re-establish a tone..and Rian Johnson decided "naaaaah". That was the beginning of the end.

I honestly think that Episode IX should have been in 2 Parts. Yeah its cliche... but JJ needed one movie to undo all TLJ stuff and set the tone back to where it was, and then Part 2 to finish taking it in the direction he wanted to finish it.

And effectively THAT would have been the trilogy.

Episode VII The Force Awakens
Episode IX The Rise of Skywalker Part 1
Episode IX The Rise of Skywalker Part 2

And that effectively would have been the "trilogy" and The Last Jedi would have been some..elseworld story.

snippet.textDisplay: Seeing a flashback of Luke and Leia train was one of the highlights for me. It makes me realize I'd rather see more of that stuff actually. I'd rather see adventures between Luke, Leia and Han after Return of the Jedi, even if they're smaller scale. No new death stars, no new emperor or empire. Just these characters we care about dealing with life after the fall of the empire. But...it's not really possible. Or more like, it wouldn't really feel right. They'd either have to continue to use the de-aging technology, and get different voice actors, or recast them in general. And it'd just feel off. It worked in this movie because it was so brief, and they didn't really speak. So it's just kind of sad that some of the things that I'd be most interested to see couldn't really actually work very well.

snippet.textDisplay: While I disagree with many of your points (myself having quite liked the movie), I quite respect your thought process for your issues for this film and the series as a whole. The fandom is absolutely nuts right now, and maybe its the nature of Star Wars itself to tear us apart. We all have crazy different opinions. For Example: I think Return of the Jedi is actually a terribly made movie that people only think is good because the Vader and Luke stuff is so good. Skywalker is a thousand times a better ending than anything in that movie in my opinion. But that's just me, and everyone else has opinions just like it or contrasting it for literally everything related to Star Wars. That's why I think I'd just like to celebrate my fandom at places like Celebration, where we can discuss and learn from each other in person rather than arguing with a screen with someone you've never met. Just my rambling thoughts, thanks for the video.

snippet.textDisplay: I also went out with my friends and was in a packed theater. We all came out with same idea, "Meh."  I truly don't get the amount of pain and suffering people receive from it.  I often wonder if people are allowing their childlike nostalgia of the originals to manipulate their perceptions of this trilogy. I'm not ignoring the faults of this series they do exist. Sidious's magic army did not make any sense. Finn still gleefully killing stormtroopers is frustrating. Rey not only cheats death but then hides her identity that she spent an entire trilogy searching for. That being said, every single Star Wars movie has HUGE GLARING faults. While The Rise of Skywalker is very far from the best Star Wars movie it did not personally hurt me and I've been a Star Wars geek since the original aired. I feel like you kids are too young to remember the disappointment that was Return of the Jedi, where we go from The Empire Strikes back to idiotic plans, killing Boba off like an asshole, New Death Star, and teddy bear monsters besting the 501st like a bunch of chumps. You kids think Rey and Kylo kissing is painful, imagine waiting 16 years  to see Darth Vader yelling out, "This is Pod Racing," while hanging with... Jar Jar motherfucking Binx. That being said your review seems like it is more so criticizing how Ryan Johnson ruined the flow of the trilogy lol.

snippet.textDisplay:
I liked your previous non-spoiler review, this one I think is clouded by your emotions. Before I saw the movie I thought Rey being a descendant of Palpatine was also a "hail mary" but there have been subtle hints.
1.) RULE OF TWO - Yoda says in the Prequel that "Always two, there are. No more, no less." The bond between Rey-Lo is real and started in the first movie.
2.) FIGHTING STYLE - Since the Force Awakens, Rey has an adaptive fighting style that MATCHES only one other person in the Star Wars Universe. The "double grip thrust" is Palpatine's killing move. He's the only one that uses this non-ethical move, Rey intuitively uses it when she first holds the lightsaber.
3.) LEITMOTIF - Star Wars has always used these character themes in their music. Palpatine had a "leitmotif", Rey has one in the Force Awakens. If you compare their themes, they are related, and only off by 2 notes. Coincidence? Not likely since it was composed 2 movies ago.
4.) RAGE - Like Anakin she has a rage that isn't a light side characteristic.
5.) ORIGIN - Both Luke an Rey grow up as orphans hidden from the Sith.



I think her temptation on the DeathStar ruins perfectly mirrors the temptation of Luke on Dagoba. Both were children of Dark Lords that chose the light. I think your emotional connection is clouding your review.This will prove to be an underrated Finale.

snippet.textDisplay:
A "C-" for a Star Wars movie? That must've ripped his heart out....

Well, same here. Just came home from the cinema and I feel sad and empty. Star Wars always had a special place in my heart because I grew up with it in the seventies and eighties. Played with all the fantastic Star Wars toys and the biggest topic in school was of course Star Wars, too. In 1983 my dad took me to the cinema for the first time and we watched "Return of the Jedi" together. It was awesome and one of the most precious moments in my life. And now, 36 years later I went to the cinema alone (my parents are both gone) and hoped for a worthy ending of the whole Skywalker-Saga and maybe a chance to indulge in those precious reminiscences of my childhood which was all about Star Wars. And well, what did I get? A boring, warmed up and uninspired version of "Return of the Jedi". Yeah, that's exactly what this movie is in my opinion. A rehash of some of the best Star Wars moments but without a new, consistent and bold storyline. And on top of that we got boring characters. Don't get me wrong here...I really like Daisy Ridley, Oscar Isaac, John Boyega and Adam Driver. And basically, I like their characters, too. (Especially Kylo Ren!) The fault is with the director(s) and the producers. They did nothing bold and/or interesting with the characters. Not over the course of two movies and especially not here, in the last FINAL movie...and they could've done SO much better. They had all the opportunities and they threw it all out of the window.
So...by now J.J. Abrams really has outdone himself. He single-handedly fucked up my most favourite movie franchises, Star Wars and Star Trek.

And now? Now we need Christopher Nolan so that he can save Star Wars like he saved Batman from oblivion. "The Jedi Begin"? "The Dark Jedi"? "The Dark Jedi Rises"? Count me in!

snippet.textDisplay: So I 100% understand where you're coming from... I'm 44 and have grown up loving Star Wars.... I think Rian Johnson is a great writer/director....maybe just not for Star Wars movies (Loved Knives Out)....I just think its unforgivable with such a valuable franchise that they could allow a 3 story arc to be written...separately....... without a good idea of where its going.... I hate the constant fake CGI/green screen of the prequels...and some of the terrible dialog....But they at least are going the same direction....I felt these movies don't even connect...its like putting puzzle pieces together from different puzzles...its going to be painful and you might get them to fit...but it will be messy .....I "Hope" that they learn from Marvel and put "1" person in charge that can write an arc for the future movies whether that's 3...6....or 9 movie...whatever... I'm not writing off the series...they have brought me far more great moments then bad...but the jarring lack of cohesion on the latest movie is a sore point.  I still thoroughly enjoyed myself at the movie because the light saber battles...and I felt there was some amazing acting.... as you stated they did the best with what they could.... and I love the "universe" ...the puppets...etc...etc...... but FTLOG  you are dealing with a billion dollar franchise can you plan more then 2 years in advance????  Someone at the top currently needs to be fired...I have some suggestions....and the ship can be righted.....  But you can't allow the same people that fkd this up...to continue..  My best friend Joel found this movie to be more painful then me...and I accept that...I've avoided arguing about the movie because its far from perfect....and usually when I argue Star Wars ....I want that time back after I'm done LOL..... But overall I did enjoy myself...and I have HOPE for the future ;)  If I didn't make it clear enough....>FTLOG plan out your movies farther in advance FFS... Thank you for a great review...  The story of you and your father was awesome to share....

snippet.textDisplay:
Chris, I normally really like your honesty and openness about genre films but I have to say within 4 minutes it was clear to me that you watched this movie twice but didn't see it. Nor do you understand the story of the new trilogy or this movie would have been clear as day to you. The ending is pretty straightforward. Rey/Kylo is a Beauty and the Beast story, a classic female archetype. For Ben to be redeemed he has to sacrifice himself for her (because that's what men do, it's one of their archetypes) and in doing so becomes worthy of her. She rewards him with acceptance and in that moment finally becomes a man. His penance for his past and the consequence of his sacrifice is that he, now as a Jedi, having faced his own death, dies.

If you can't see that, if you can't see how simple and true that is both to Star Wars and heroic cycles/the big story, then I suggest you find a different medium to cover. Because this is your job as a critic. It's your job to cut through the noise, see the underlying story and help us make sense of what we saw. And, honestly, you failed here in the most basic way.

I'm sad you are too close to both the industry and Star Wars to see this clearly because, as a critic, you had so much potential.
snippet.textOriginal:

Rey/Kylo is a Beauty and the Beast story, a classic female archetype. She rewards him with acceptance and in that moment finally becomes a man. Because this is your job as a critic.  It's your job to cut through the noise, see the underlying story and help us make sense of what we saw.  And, honestly, you failed here in the most basic way.

I'm sad you are too close to both the industry and Star Wars to see this clearly because, as a critic, you had so much potential.

snippet.textDisplay: Say it! The kiss was so "incestuous", the set up was much more like siblings... their twin like connection, their yinyang force personas, even mom/dad/uncle adopting Rey. The first movie set the characters up to feel like there was going to be some sort of familial reveal... even the title of this last film... then they kiss! ewwwww! I told my husband I would have been more for Poe and Finn kissing at the end, since they had more romantic chemistry(harkening back to leia and han). I also felt they both should have died or they both should have lived in order to really stick the landing on the end, either they should both die and the force be distributed to all beings in the form of the conscience Fin mentioned(also staying withing the biblical references of the series) or they should both live and Ben, as penance, is not setting out across the universes righting wrongs... Either way, how the hell does Ben get a Jedi death and then he isn't seen by Rey when she announces she is a Skywalker?!?! WTF?!?!!

There were a lot of cringe moments. This movie feels like it's trying too hard to appease everyone. So many new characters that I didn't care about and made little impact. Anyway here are two things amongst many other terrible decisions that made me retch.


1. Rey's ridiculous Arc. Force Awakens - might be somebody. Last Jedi - definitely nobody. Rise of Skywalker - Definitely somebody.
2. Palpatine's nonsensical ravings to Kylo Ren: Kill the girl at all cost. Kill Rey. Rey survives and now stands before Palpatine. Palpatine: You finally made it home to complete your training. This is what we've been waiting for. Huh?!

snippet.textDisplay: I really wish they didn't bring Palps back in this movie, the most interesting part of TLJ for me was the decision to kill Snoke and close the film with Kylo as the big bad but we don't see any of that in rise of Skywalker, just a minute of him wrecking shop at the beginning and then BOOM he's back to being some big almighty's whipping boy! It would have been real interesting to see a character as conflicted as him in a position of absolute power and how the heroes would deal with that. I also liked the idea that Rey really was born from nobodys and that she was just naturally powerful just for the sake of balance, it would've been nice to see her struggle with that concept and how to control herself over the course of the trilogy. The force awakens and pieces of the last jedi really introduced good foundations and they really just did nothing to flesh any of it out.

snippet.textDisplay:
I just don’t want people blaming Johnson. Cause man I seriously just can’t stand the Johnson hate. Look if you don’t love the movie, I can understand that. I personally loved Last Jedi and think it has great compelling themes and ideas, great character arcs, and interesting thoughts. Is it perfect, maybe not, but truthfully no Star Wars film really is perfect.
But Abrams backing away from Johnson’s stuff I feel is at minimum just as bad, if not worse than Johnson doing his own thing, because Abrams passed the baton to him.
I’m not blaming Abrams necessarily either, but my point being is the film really feels like it caves to fan hate of: Rey’s lineage, Rose, Holdo, and more. And I really feel like it shouldn’t have.
Maybe Disney/the execs are the real issue by not laying out a direct road map and giving too much creative freedom to the directors, and even caving to fans too much, I don’t really know. I don’t envy the job.
But I guess what I’m saying is don’t actively hate and dismiss and spout cruelty towards Johnson and don’t put the blame on his shoulders. He was handed the franchise and made the film he felt was the best continuation of it, and though it has flaws, there’s a lot of good in it. It’s also just not nice to spout hate towards an individual, and it already drove Kelly Marie Tran off of social media. Just be civil about stuff whilst also providing constructive criticism.

snippet.textDisplay:
I honestly don't understand why people liked the original Star Wars. It was cartoonish and none of the characters were deep. It was full of plot holes and the villain was not compelling either. If it was meant to be a cartoon, I can think of tons of Japanese animations that were better. I mean Valley of Wind was far more imaginative, had better characters and morally ambiguous villains. In the Manga, the heroine realized that while the forest was cleaning the air, her people were used to the toxic and would choke in clean air. She had to choose whether to save her people or let the earth heal. That's the kind of tough decisions heroes should be making, not I am not joining this evil laughing fool.

Instead of an evil villain, the emperor could have represented something. Maybe he was disenfranchised by democracy and decided to bring order to the galaxy. Even Megatron, as shallow as he was, had "Peace through Tyranny". Nope, the emperor just laughed some evil laughs and likes to be evil.

Why do people like Star Wars anyway?
